name: Tamarind Rice
history: Tamarind Rice, locally known as Puliyodarai, is a traditional South Indian dish. It's a staple in Tamil Nadu and is often served in temples as prasadam. The dish is known for its tangy and spicy flavor, derived from tamarind and various spices.
description: Tamarind Rice is a flavorful dish where cooked rice is mixed with a spicy and tangy tamarind paste, which includes spices like mustard seeds, chilies, and curry leaves. It's a popular choice for packed lunches or travel, as it keeps well.

instructions.title: Cook the Rice
instructions.description: Cook the rice until it's fluffy and separate. Allow it to cool.

instructions.title: Prepare the Tamarind Paste
instructions.description: In a pan, heat sesame oil. Add mustard seeds, urad dal, chana dal, dry red chilies, asafoetida, and curry leaves. Once the mustard seeds start spluttering, add the tamarind paste, turmeric powder, and jaggery or sugar if using. Cook until it thickens.

instructions.title: Mix Rice and Tamarind Paste
instructions.description: Add the cooked rice to the tamarind mixture. Mix gently ensuring the rice is evenly coated with the paste. Season with salt.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the tamarind rice warm or at room temperature. It can be garnished with roasted peanuts and fresh coriander.

tips: Ensure the rice is not overcooked to maintain texture in the dish.
Adjust the amount of tamarind to suit your taste for tanginess.
variations: Add vegetables like green peas or bell peppers for a more nutritious dish.
For a spicier version, increase the quantity of red chilies.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat in a microwave or on a stovetop with a little added water.
presentationTips: Serve in a bowl, garnished with extra peanuts and a wedge of lemon.
Pair with a simple yogurt raita or papad for a complete meal.
